Description: Pottery: coarse ware basket vase. A double-faced pot, oval in cross-section, with a basket-handle: on one side is the face of a maenad, with a frowning brow and prominent lines bracketing her dimpled chin; she has curls on top of her head and vertical locks falling to her brow and framing her face. The other side has the face of a young satyr with a closely woven wreath adorned with ivy berries crossing above his forehead, his hair showing above and falling beside his face. The resting-surface of the pot is slightly concave. Two-piece mould, with applied handle above. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt, with the remains of a white dressing outside and in, but not under the base; a little black paint survives on the eyes, and the face of the maenad is painted pink; the hair of the satyr has red paint, and pink paint was used on his wreath.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Near: 3665 above; Bayer- Niemeier 1988: no. 763, dated second to third century ad; Breccia 1934: no. 394; Fischer 1994: no. 1254, dated end of second, beginning of third century ad.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3666)
